ygData.subject: Re: rtNEAT in Sensor Network
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi, Ken Thanks for your reply. you are right, there are many restrictions to use AI into sensor network. One of the most important issue is the battery energy,

Hi, Ken

Thanks for your reply. 

you are right, there are many restriction=
s to use AI into sensor
network. One of the most important issue is the bat=
tery energy, which
will be affected by the communication consumption in mos=
t of the case. 
Therefore, we need to reduce the frequence for communicatio=
n among
sensor nodes as much as possible. 

So 'you are running a separate =
evolution population inside each sensor
node' is the way that we WANT to ru=
n our experiments. But problem is
that sensor node might not have much proc=
essing ability as PC, we
switch to your second option 'all the sensor nodes=
 part of one large
population' but with each sensor node (they might measur=
e different
quantities) will have its own prediction system. 

I guess this=
 is one of the difference between project of sensor
network with those in y=
our group, that in most of your projects one
population will have one sole =
solution --- the best one among them ---
and deploy this best solution into=
 robot, and therefore in a real
project, e.g. vedio game, there are many of=
 such population to support
many robots. Am I right?

the communication in =
sensor network is local (so is the measurement
and fitness of each sensor),=
 the result from each sensor will be a
local solution. But the global solut=
ion will be given by all the
sensor nodes in the newtork. We hope we can so=
lve this 'global'
problem in the future.

sorry that I have misunderstood w=
hat 'real-time' means in rtNEAT. The
reason why I concern about 'real-time'=
 is because I want to find
solution that can be trained continuously with o=
ne or couple piece of
measurement data (not a long history of data in offli=
ne case). 

Joe



--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley=
@...> wrote:
>
> Joe, from your description I am not certain whether you ne=
ed 
> the "rt" (real-time) part of rtNEAT.  Am I understanding right that 
=
> you are running a separate evolution population inside each sensor 
> nod=
e?  Or are all the sensor nodes part of one large population?  In 
> the la=
tter case, it is more likely that rtNEAT might help, but there 
> are still=
 a lot of issues specific to the domain.  (For example, if 
> communication=
 is only local than global variables cannot be 
> guaranteed.)  
> 
> My gu=
ess without a lot of background is that this will be a 
> difficult domain =
to fit into rtNEAT's framework.  However, I could 
> be wrong as I don't kn=
ow exactly what would be measured as fitness.
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yah=
oogroups.com, "ghuaien" <ghuaien@> wrote:
> >
> > 
> > 
> > I am currently =
working on the project of sensor network where I 
> would
> > like to use n=
eural network as forcast system in each sensor node.
> > 
> > I would like =
to compare my result with that of rtNEAT (if rtNEAT 
> can
> > meet our req=
uirement in sensor system).
> > 
> > To my best knowledge, rtNEAT can do re=
al time processing if the
> > computational power is strong enough (because=
 of the population is
> > generally large, e.g. 100 --- even though it is n=
ot a large 
> population
> > in terms of statistics). But since sensor node=
 will only possess 
> basic
> > processing ability, I am not sure if rtNEAT=
 can be applied in such
> > scenario or not .. AND, just to want to make it=
 clear: we are 
> looking
> > for the solution system which can do training=
 online and which 
> will be
> > deployed inside one sensor node (so that e=
ach sensor will have
> > embedded rtNEAT model, e.g.).
> > 
> > (in my case=
, I will deploy one neural network system with roughly 
> 100
> > number of=
 sypnaptic connections inside the sensor node, in order to
> > keep the com=
putation cost --- for training --- low)
> > 
> > Can any one help me throug=
h ?
> > 
> > Thanks alot
> > 
> > Joe
